subject_terms_3: Khoo, Sui Hoe Oil painting Lim, Chong Keat Singapore Conference Hall
physical_appearance: This is a large multicolored painting. It is in the shape of a square. It depicts seven figurative figures in various positions, using bright colours and defined shapes. There is a bright, circular shape at the top-center of the painting, with yellow and white wavey lines portruding from it. In from of the circular shape, there is a figure painted in shades of green, with an arm stretched upwards. At the bottom of the painting, one figure is resting on an open stylised plant with outstretched leaves. There are no signatures seen.
sgcool_label_text: Children of the Sun is one of the few works undertaken by the artist on such a monumental scale. It could be considered an early work, but is deeply intertwined with the artists’ interest in the figurative form. The history of the painting intertwines deeply with the national development of Singapore. The Children of the Sun was first commissioned for the opening of the Singapore Conference Hall (currently a National Monument). The painting was then kept on display in the lounge of the conference hall. Painted in 1965 at Datuk Seri Lim’s Pasir Panjang seaside cottage, the Children of the Sun was the first major large painting by Khoo Sui Hoe.
